Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrated Research and Educational Plan to Develop Selective Pyrolysis Reactors and Improve the Capacity of Students to Work in Multidisciplinary Teams

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
(Garcia-Perez)1150430

Intellectual merit of the proposed activity: Distributed fast pyrolysis units located close to biomass resources could convert between 60 and 75 % of lignocellulosic materials into crude bio-oils of which 40 % could be further transformed into transportation fuels via hydrotreatment in rural or centralized bio-oil refineries. In spite the importance of these reactors, the available knowledge on kinetics and transport phenomena in lignocellulosic materials has not been properly integrated for the design of pyrolysis reactors. The mechanism of lignin pyrolysis reactions responsible for the production of precursors of transportation fuels (mono phenols and lignin oligomers) also remains poorly studied. This proposal will advance the understanding of lignin pyrolysis reactions and the associated transport phenomena to support the development of multi-scale mathematical models for the design of selective pyrolysis reactors and take advantage of the problems associated with the design of these reactors to developed multidisciplinary team working skills in K-12, undergraduate and graduate students.

The research component involves integrated experimental and simulation tasks that will allow for the identification of conditions maximizing the production of precursors of transportation fuels from the pyrolysis of lignocellulosic materials. The approach proposed to design selective Auger pyrolysis reactors requires a detailed understanding of the kinetics of primary and secondary reactions, the evaporation and cracking of liquid intermediates, heat and mass transfer at the cell level, particle size and solid residence time distribution and a model to describe the behavior of single biomass particles.

The proposed project will advance the understanding of lignin depolymerization reactions stressing on the role of lignin liquid intermediates as precursors for the production of lignin oligomers. A multi-scale mathematical model will be developed to design selective Auger pyrolysis reactors. For the first time this model will integrate (1) new kinetic models for lignin pyrolysis, (2) a model to describe the effect of the evolving biomass cell structures on the effective axial and radial thermal conductivity and mass diffusivity and (3) a single particle model that takes into account axial and radial heat and mass transfer and secondary reactions to identify the conditions which maximize the production of precursors of transportation fuels.

Broader impact: The kinetic parameters of lignin pyrolysis that will result from this project, in conjunction with kinetic information reported in the literature, will support the development of multi-scale models to design and evaluate more selective pyrolysis reactors. This contribution is significant because the expected gains in the production of precursors of transportation fuels from lignocellulosic materials could significantly increase the production of bio-fuels and reduce the nation's dependency on imported oil. The development of a systematic methodology to design pyrolysis reactors will be a significant contribution to future research on the design of other thermochemical reactors such as gasification and torrefaction reactors. Thus, the outcome of this project is not only expected to fundamentally advance the field of biomass thermo-chemical conversion but also have broad and highly positive societal impacts.

An educational plan to develop multidisciplinary team working skills in K-12, undergraduate and graduate students working in the development of selective pyrolysis reactors will be implemented and assessed. Thus the educational component of this proposal will also have a wide reaching impact because it will be conducted in such a way that will contribute to the teaching of K-12, undergraduate and graduate students to work in multidisciplinary teams while developing teaching modules, experimental set-ups and designs of selective pyrolysis reactors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distributed fast pyrolysis units located close to biomass resources could convert between 60 and 75 % of lignocellulosic materials into crude bio-oils of which 40 % could be further transformed into transportation fuels via hydrotreatment in rural or centralized bio-oil refineries. In spite of the importance of pyrolysis reactors, the mechanism of lignin and cellulose pyrolysis reactions remains poorly known. The available knowledge on kinetics and transport phonomena of this reaction system has not been properly integrated for the the design of pyrolysis reactors. This project contributed to advance the science and technology for the implementation of this model of biomass economy. The design characteristics of pyrolysis reactors was reviewed and a new theory stressing on the role of oligomeric products was developed. We made major progresses on the characterization of pyrolysis oils. Our new understanding of bio-oil chemistry is a critical step to propose new separation strategies and bio-products that will eventually lead to viable bio-oil refineries. The new Raman, NMR and XPS biochar characterization methods developed are helping our team to better understand biochar formation mechanisms and material properties. This information is needed for the design of engineered biochars for environmental services. Our team took advantage of the tasks associated with the design and modelling of pyrolysis reactors to develop multidisciplinary team working skills in K-12, undergraduate and graduate students. We also worked with the Walla Walla community college in the development and assessment of an associate degree program in plants operation.

Intellecual merit: This project advanced our understanding of cellulose and lignin depolymerization reactions with important contributions to understand  the role of oligomeric molecules on primary and secondary reactions.Parametric studies were used to measure how the yield and composition of lignin oligomers changed with vapors residence time, temperature and particle size. Vacuum pyrolysis studies in a wire mesh reactor confirmed that cellulose primary products are anhydrosugars covering a wide range of degree of polymerization. The experimental results obtained with high resolution mass spectroscopy confirmed the importance of cellulose dehydration and lignin condensation reactions in the liquid intermediate. The formation of "pyrolytic humins" as a major product of cellulose pyrolysis was identified for the first time. New modeling and experimental tools were developed to study the thermal ejection mechanism responsible for the removal of oligomers from the liquid intermediate. Models were developed to describe thermochemical reactions, bubbling and thermal ejection intensity, and the behavior of biomass particles.Our team also made important contributions with new analytical methods for the characterization of bio-oil and biochar. For the first time we were able to quantify 100 % of the bio-oil produced. More than twenty five peer reviewed manuscripts were published.

Broader impact: The new information obtained changed our understanding of the nature of pyrolysis reactions and the factors affecting the yield and composition of products. This new understanding is being used in the development of more selective pyrolysis reactors. This information is also relevant to study the impact of forest fires. Several new oligomeric families released during forest fires were identified. The new knowledge obtained on bio-oil chemistry is critical to develop rational strategies to refine these oils. The new methods developed for the analysis of Raman, XPS and 13C-NMR spectra are helping our team to design bio-chars for targeted environmental applications.  More than thirty K-12 and undergradate students received training as part of the internship program created by this project. This project also served as research subject for 7 PhD dissertation (all of them successfully completed). Twenty undergraduate students did their capstone project in subjects related with the design and construction of pyrolysis reactors. As part of this project we also worked with the Walla Walla community college creating and implementing a new curriculum for the training of plant operators. One educational research paper with the assessment of this program was published and one more was submitted. Thus, this project did not only advance the field of biomass thermochemical conversion but also had broad and highly positive societal impacts.
